{"title":"page 46","subjec":{},"descri":{},"creato":{},"publis":{},"date":{},"year":{},"format":{},"reposi":{},"collec":{},"reposa":{},"rights":{},"digitb":{},"langua":{},"topics":{},"cite":{},"notes":{},"notesa":{},"source":{},"box":{},"folder":{},"identi":{},"relati":{},"findin":{},"catalo":{},"type":{},"full":"46
Sec. 24. The Lieutenant of the District in which
the fire maybe, will, until the arrival of the Chief
of Police, give directions to the Lieutenants of other
Districts, who may be present with their men, as to
the position they shall take with their men ; and
the Lieutenants of other Districts will report themselves to the Lieutenant of the District in which
the fire may be.
RIOTS.
Sec. 25. In case of riot, or any disturbance re-,
quiring a large force, the policemen on the beat or
station will immediately give notice to the officer
in charge at the Police Station House; who will
without delay and as secretly as possible proceed
with his men to the spot.
Sec. 26. If he have any doubt of his ability to
restore order or preserve the peace, he will immediately send notice to Lieutenants of other Districts
and to the Chief of Police.
Sec. 27. The policemen under the direction of
their proper officers will use every exertion to restore order, and disperse the persons assembled, but
